body: Build started.
Thanks @mengxr ! LGTM with passing tests.

Not sure if you intended to make this work, but local: doesn't work in the context of running yarn-cluster mode and specifying the --jar?

./bin/spark-class org.apache.spark.deploy.yarn.Client         --jar local:/home/tgraves/test2/tgravescs-spark/examples/target/scala-2.10/spark-examples_2.10-assembly-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar     --class org.apache.spark.examples.SparkPi --args yarn-cluster 

local: also doesn't work with the spark-shell in yarn-client mode.  I'm fine with filing a separate jira for that.  We should document in the jira that it is only in the yarn-cluster mode.

@tgravescs Your browser is not funky. The current implementation triggers an asynchronous log fetch every time the browser refreshes, so by the time the first refresh is done, the logs have not been processed yet. I realize this behavior is probably not desired and I will push out a fix shortly.

Also, to update others who are following this conversation. The exception reported in [SPARK-1407](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-1407) turned out to be due to not properly finishing the application (i.e. through the shutdown hook triggered by System.exit without directly invoking `sc.stop()`). This is not a bug inherent in the event logging interface or the HistoryServer, AFAIK.
Merged build finished. All automated tests passed.

All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13913/
Jenkins, test this please

Also @tgraves, I have not tried to render thousands of apps, but from what I've experienced on the SparkUI's stage page, which displays thousands of tasks sometimes, loading the HTML becomes much slower. In other words, as you suspected, the UI doesn't scale super well. I think the correct thing to do here is to add pagination (which may or may not go out with this PR).

We can set the retained applications higher. I started it at 20 just because I was testing locally. The thing is the size of each ApplicationHistoryInfo may vary widely across applications, because each of them contains a SparkUI, which holds various data structures whose sizes scale with the number of tasks. For now, however, we will rotate on the granularity of applications, because this is much simpler.

Having a link back to the HistoryServer is definitely nice. However, the re-rendered SparkUI goes through the same code path as the live SparkUI, which has no backward link currently. This would require a larger refactor for the UI in general. I can imagine an optional `Back` tab that floats to the right of the header bar that takes you back. I plan to add this in the future, though for Spark 1.0 the HistoryServer will for the most part have only the most basic functionality, seeing that the release date is slowly encroaching upon us...

Thanks for your feedback.
Code changes look good other then the above mentioned use cases.
Thanks @holdenk - merged!

@pwendell Shall we use the package name `spark.annotation` instead of `spark.annotations`? We have `util` and `rdd` without `s`.
I vote for spark.annotation, package names are generally singular, e.g., "javax.annotation" which I think trumps Hadoop any day.
That is the artifact name. Java uses `annotation`: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/annotation/Documented.html
Thanks - merged with some minor changes.
Okay - I'll change this to `annotation`

Actually one more thing, can you set copy=true in astype (or just not set it)? I'm not sure that it preserves the right byte order and such and I know that this works with copy=true. Also we don't want to mess with the user's input data.
Sorry meant true, not false.

I don't have any ideas. cc @jegonzal @dcrankshaw

Hi @kanzhang, we have a long-running discussion about this at #251. Joining on the thread is a simple alternative to what is proposed in the other PR, but at the same time preserves clear semantics (i.e. all events before STOP will be processed to completion, and no events after STOP will be processed). Both @pwendell and I are inclined towards this approach.

Could you add a test for this? #251 provided an excellent example of this. @concretevitamin could we use your test case here? We'll be sure to credit both of you.
Jenkins, test this please.
